lines.text: Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: What, John! What, Robert!

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Quickly, quickly! is the buck-basket--

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: I warrant. What, Robin, I say!
Enter Servants with a basket

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Come, come, come.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Here, set it down.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Give your men the charge; we must be brief.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Marry, as I told you before, John and Robert, be ready here hard by in the brew-house: and when I suddenly call you, come forth, and without any pause or staggering take this basket on your shoulders: that done, trudge with it in all haste, and carry it among the whitsters in Datchet-mead, and there empty it in the muddy ditch close by the Thames side.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: You will do it?

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: I ha' told them over and over; they lack no direction. Be gone, and come when you are called.
Exeunt Servants

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Here comes little Robin.
Enter ROBIN

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: How now, my eyas-musket! what news with you?

lines.speaker: robin
lines.text: My master, Sir John, is come in at your back-door, Mistress Ford, and requests your company.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: You little Jack-a-Lent, have you been true to us?

lines.speaker: robin
lines.text: Ay, I'll be sworn. My master knows not of your being here and hath threatened to put me into everlasting liberty if I tell you of it; for he swears he'll turn me away.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Thou'rt a good boy: this secrecy of thine shall be a tailor to thee and shall make thee a new doublet and hose. I'll go hide me.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Do so. Go tell thy master I am alone. Mistress Page, remember you your cue.
Exit ROBIN

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: I warrant thee; if I do not act it, hiss me.
Exit

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Go to, then: we'll use this unwholesome humidity, this gross watery pumpion; we'll teach him to know turtles from jays.
Enter FALSTAFF

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Have I caught thee, my heavenly jewel? Why, now let me die, for I have lived long enough: this is the period of my ambition: O this blessed hour!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: O sweet Sir John!

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Mistress Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate, Mistress Ford. Now shall I sin in my wish: I would thy husband were dead: I'll speak it before the best lord; I would make thee my lady.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: I your lady, Sir John! alas, I should be a pitiful lady!

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Let the court of France show me such another. I see how thine eye would emulate the diamond: thou hast the right arched beauty of the brow that becomes the ship-tire, the tire-valiant, or any tire of Venetian admittance.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: A plain kerchief, Sir John: my brows become nothing else; nor that well neither.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: By the Lord, thou art a traitor to say so: thou wouldst make an absolute courtier; and the firm fixture of thy foot would give an excellent motion to thy gait in a semi-circled farthingale. I see what thou wert, if Fortune thy foe were not, Nature thy friend. Come, thou canst not hide it.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Believe me, there is no such thing in me.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: What made me love thee? let that persuade thee there's something extraordinary in thee. Come, I cannot cog and say thou art this and that, like a many of these lisping hawthorn-buds, that come like women in men's apparel, and smell like Bucklersbury in simple time; I cannot: but I love thee; none but thee; and thou deservest it.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Do not betray me, sir. I fear you love Mistress Page.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Thou mightst as well say I love to walk by the Counter-gate, which is as hateful to me as the reek of a lime-kiln.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Well, heaven knows how I love you; and you shall one day find it.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Keep in that mind; I'll deserve it.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Nay, I must tell you, so you do; or else I could not be in that mind.

lines.speaker: robin
lines.text: [Within]  Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford! here's Mistress Page at the door, sweating and blowing and looking wildly, and would needs speak with you presently.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: She shall not see me: I will ensconce me behind the arras.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Pray you, do so: she's a very tattling woman. What's the matter? how now!
FALSTAFF hides himself
Re-enter MISTRESS PAGE and ROBIN

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: O Mistress Ford, what have you done? You're shamed, you're overthrown, you're undone for ever!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: What's the matter, good Mistress Page?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: O well-a-day, Mistress Ford! having an honest man to your husband, to give him such cause of suspicion!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: What cause of suspicion?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: What cause of suspicion! Out pon you! how am I mistook in you!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Why, alas, what's the matter?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Your husband's coming hither, woman, with all the officers in Windsor, to search for a gentleman that he says is here now in the house by your consent, to take an ill advantage of his assence: you are undone.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: 'Tis not so, I hope.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Pray heaven it be not so, that you have such a man here! but 'tis most certain your husband's coming, with half Windsor at his heels, to search for such a one. I come before to tell you. If you know yourself clear, why, I am glad of it; but if you have a friend here convey, convey him out. Be not amazed; call all your senses to you; defend your reputation, or bid farewell to your good life for ever.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: What shall I do? There is a gentleman my dear friend; and I fear not mine own shame so much as his peril: I had rather than a thousand pound he were out of the house.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: For shame! never stand 'you had rather' and 'you had rather:' your husband's here at hand, bethink you of some conveyance: in the house you cannot hide him. O, how have you deceived me! Look, here is a basket: if he be of any reasonable stature, he may creep in here; and throw foul linen upon him, as if it were going to bucking: or--it is whiting-time --send him by your two men to Datchet-mead.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: He's too big to go in there. What shall I do?

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: [Coming forward]  Let me see't, let me see't, O, let me see't! I'll in, I'll in. Follow your friend's counsel. I'll in.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: What, Sir John Falstaff! Are these your letters, knight?

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: I love thee. Help me away. Let me creep in here. I'll never-- Gets into the basket; they cover him with foul linen

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Help to cover your master, boy. Call your men, Mistress Ford. You dissembling knight!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: What, John! Robert! John! Go take up these clothes here quickly. Where's the cowl-staff? look, how you drumble! Carry them to the laundress in Datchet-meat; quickly, come.
Exit ROBIN
Re-enter Servants
Enter FORD, PAGE, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Pray you, come near: if I suspect without cause, why then make sport at me; then let me be your jest; I deserve it. How now! whither bear you this?

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: To the laundress, forsooth.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Why, what have you to do whither they bear it? You were best meddle with buck-washing.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Buck! I would I could wash myself of the buck! Buck, buck, buck! Ay, buck; I warrant you, buck; and of the season too, it shall appear. Gentlemen, I have dreamed to-night; I'll tell you my dream. Here, here, here be my keys: ascend my chambers; search, seek, find out: I'll warrant we'll unkennel the fox. Let me stop this way first. So, now uncape.
Exeunt Servants with the basket
Locking the door

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Good Master Ford, be contented: you wrong yourself too much.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: True, Master Page. Up, gentlemen: you shall see sport anon: follow me, gentlemen.
Exit

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: This is fery fantastical humours and jealousies.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: By gar, 'tis no the fashion of France; it is not jealous in France.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Nay, follow him, gentlemen; see the issue of his search.
Exeunt PAGE, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Is there not a double excellency in this?

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: I know not which pleases me better, that my husband is deceived, or Sir John.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: What a taking was he in when your husband asked who was in the basket!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: I am half afraid he will have need of washing; so throwing him into the water will do him a benefit.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Hang him, dishonest rascal! I would all of the same strain were in the same distress.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: I think my husband hath some special suspicion of Falstaff's being here; for I never saw him so gross in his jealousy till now.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: I will lay a plot to try that; and we will yet have more tricks with Falstaff: his dissolute disease will scarce obey this medicine.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Shall we send that foolish carrion, Mistress Quickly, to him, and excuse his throwing into the water; and give him another hope, to betray him to another punishment?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: We will do it: let him be sent for to-morrow, eight o'clock, to have amends.
Re-enter FORD, PAGE, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: I cannot find him: may be the knave bragged of that he could not compass.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: [Aside to MISTRESS FORD]  Heard you that?

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: You use me well, Master Ford, do you?

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Ay, I do so.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Heaven make you better than your thoughts!

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Amen!

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: You do yourself mighty wrong, Master Ford.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Ay, ay; I must bear it.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: If there be any pody in the house, and in the chambers, and in the coffers, and in the presses, heaven forgive my sins at the day of judgment!

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: By gar, nor I too: there is no bodies.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Fie, fie, Master Ford! are you not ashamed? What spirit, what devil suggests this imagination? I would not ha' your distemper in this kind for the wealth of Windsor Castle.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: 'Tis my fault, Master Page: I suffer for it.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: You suffer for a pad conscience: your wife is as honest a 'omans as I will desires among five thousand, and five hundred too.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: By gar, I see 'tis an honest woman.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Well, I promised you a dinner. Come, come, walk in the Park: I pray you, pardon me; I will hereafter make known to you why I have done this. Come, wife; come, Mistress Page. I pray you, pardon me; pray heartily, pardon me.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Let's go in, gentlemen; but, trust me, we'll mock him. I do invite you to-morrow morning to my house to breakfast: after, we'll a-birding together; I have a fine hawk for the bush. Shall it be so?

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Any thing.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: If there is one, I shall make two in the company.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: If dere be one or two, I shall make-a the turd.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Pray you, go, Master Page.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: I pray you now, remembrance tomorrow on the lousy knave, mine host.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: Dat is good; by gar, with all my heart!

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: A lousy knave, to have his gibes and his mockeries!
Exeunt
